DataElement.preferredName: B Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Symptom Diagnosis Timepoint Present Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The text response that indicates symptom(s) present at the time of diagnosis with B-Cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: B Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Symptom Diagnosis Timepoint Present
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The most frequent type of acute lymphoblastic leukemia.  Approximately 75% of cases occur in children under six years of age.  This is a good prognosis leukemia.  In the pediatric age group the complete remission rate is approximately 95% and the disease free survival rate is 70%.  Approximately 80% of children appear to be cured.  In the adult age group the complete remission rate is 60-85%.  (WHO, 2001)_Subjective evidence of disease perceived by the patient._The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation._A specific point in the time continuum, including those established relative to an event._Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

In the adult age group the complete remission rate is 60-85%.  (WHO, 2001):Subjective evidence of disease perceived by the patient.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: signs that a person has a condition or disease. Some examples of symptoms are headache, fever, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, and pain(NCI).
